column1: Breast lump removal is surgery to remove a lump that may be breast cancer.
When a noncancerous tumor such as a fibroadenoma of the breast is removed, it is often called an excisional breast biopsybreast biopsy, instead of a lumpectomy.
- A radiologist will use a mammogram or ultrasound to place a needlewire (or needlewires) in or near the abnormal breast area.
The surgeon makes a small cut on your breast and removes the cancer and some of the normal breast tissue around it.
- To see if cancer has spread to the lymph nodes, your surgeon may also remove lymph nodes in your armpit.
It may be hard to know whether lumpectomy or mastectomy (removal of the entire breast) is best.

You and your doctor should consider: - The size of your tumor - Where it is in your breast - If there is more than one tumor - How much of the breast is affected - The size of your breasts - Your age - Your family history - Your general health, including whether you have reached menopause
Risks for any surgery are: - Bleeding - Infection - Reactions to medicines The appearance of your breast may change after surgery.

Always tell your doctor or nurse: - If you could be pregnant - What drugs you are taking, even drugs or herbs you bought without a prescription During the days before your surgery: - You may be asked to stop taking aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin), naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn), clopidogrel (Plavix), warfarin (Coumadin), and any other drugs that make it hard for your blood to clot.
Many women have little pain, but if you do feel pain, you can take pain medicine, such as acetaminophen.
A lumpectomy for breast cancer is usually followed by radiation therapy and treatment such as chemotherapy, hormone therapy, or both.
